name: High-Performance Executives
description: C-suite professionals and entrepreneurs who view optimal health as critical for peak performance and leadership effectiveness. They have the highest disposable income and prioritize time-efficient solutions that deliver measurable results for energy, focus, and stress resilience.
sociodemographics: 40-55, 65% women, $200k+ income, major urban centers, executive/entrepreneurial roles

name: Health-Optimizing Tech Professionals
description: Data-driven technology workers who approach health with the same systematic methodology they use in their careers. They extensively track biomarkers, love innovative solutions, and are early adopters of science-backed health technologies.
sociodemographics: 32-42, 55% women, $120k+ income, tech hubs (SF, Seattle, Austin, London, Berlin)

name: Wellness-Focused Healthcare Workers
description: Medical professionals, nurses, and healthcare practitioners who understand the limitations of conventional medicine and seek evidence-based preventive solutions. Their professional knowledge makes them highly discerning but also more trusting of legitimate science.

name: Digestive-Issue Strugglers
description: Individuals with chronic digestive problems who have exhausted mainstream medical solutions and supplements without lasting relief. They are desperate for effective solutions and willing to pay premium prices for products that actually work.
sociodemographics: 35-55, 75% women, $80k+ income, various locations, often with autoimmune conditions

name: Family Health Guardians
description: Parents who take primary responsibility for their family's health decisions and are seeking foundational nutrition solutions for the whole household. They balance personal optimization with family wellness and prefer convenient, kid-friendly options.
sociodemographics: 35-48, 85% women, $120k+ household income, affluent suburbs, various professions

name: Functional Medicine Advocates
description: Individuals who work with functional medicine practitioners and understand root-cause approaches to health. They are educated about gut-health connections and seek products that address underlying mechanisms rather than symptoms.
sociodemographics: 40-58, 75% women, $130k+ income, health-progressive areas, various professions

name: Recovery-Focused Athletes
description: Fitness enthusiasts and amateur athletes who train intensively and understand that gut health impacts recovery, inflammation, and performance. They seek clean, whole-food solutions that complement their training regimens without artificial additives.
sociodemographics: 32-48, 50% women, $110k+ income, active lifestyle communities, various professions

name: Supplement-Disappointed Skeptics
description: Former supplement enthusiasts who have spent significant money on products like AG1, probiotics, and digestive enzymes without seeing results. They are now highly cautious but still searching for authentic solutions with transparent science.
sociodemographics: 38-52, 70% women, $100k+ income, health-conscious areas, various professions

name: Biohacking Enthusiasts
description: Self-optimization devotees who follow health influencers, experiment with cutting-edge wellness technologies, and are constantly seeking the next breakthrough in human performance. They appreciate innovative delivery methods and novel approaches.

name: Energy-Seeking Professionals
description: Mid-career professionals experiencing energy crashes, brain fog, and declining vitality who suspect gut health is the root cause. They want solutions that fit seamlessly into busy schedules while delivering noticeable improvements in daily energy.
